title: A breathtaking account of the Eighties – from Margaret Thatcher to Terry and June
text:
There’s a revelation for every reader in Dominic Sandbrook’s Who Dares Wins, a superb study of a transformational time for Britain, says Simon Heffer

The label “popular history” is often used belittlingly by academics. Some popular histories may well be potboilers, but those written by Dominic Sandbrook, of which this is the fifth volume, are nothing of the sort. Like its predecessors, which run from Suez to the Winter of Discontent, this study of the early Thatcher years is immaculately well-researched, breathtakingly broad and beautifully written. One defies anyone, even a specialist, not to learn something from it.

The book opens in May 1980. Margaret Thatcher, of whom Sandbrook is...
